    • Moult data likelihoods and model priors

    Moult data likelihoods and model priors

    moult-likelihoods.Rmd

    The moultmcmc package implements the regression models outlined in Les G. Underhill and Zucchini (1988) and L. G. Underhill, Zucchini, and Summers (1990). In their notation1, samples consist of II pre-moult birds, JJ birds in active moult, and KK post-moult birds. Birds in each category are observed on days t=t1,â€¦,tIt = t_1,\ldots,t_I; u=u1,â€¦,uJu = u_1,\ldots,u_J; v=v1,â€¦,vKv = v_1,\ldots,v_K, respectively. Moult scores for actively moulting birds, where available, are encoded as y=y1,â€¦,yJy = y_1,\ldots,y_J.

    Each moult state has a probability of occurrence P(t)=Pr{Y(t)=0}=1âˆ’FT(t)Q(t)=Pr{0<Y(t)<1}=FT(t)âˆ’FT(tâˆ’Ï„)R(t)=Pr{Y(t)=1}=1âˆ’FT(tâˆ’Ï„) \begin{aligned} P(t) &= \Pr\{Y(t)=0\}&= &1-F_T(t)\\ Q(t) &= \Pr\{0<Y(t)<1\}& =&F_T(t)-F_T(t-\tau)\\ R(t) &= \Pr\{Y(t)=1\}&= &1-F_T(t-\tau)\\ \end{aligned} Further, assuming a linear progression of the moult indices over time, the probability density of a particular moult score at time tt is fY(t)(y)=Ï„fT(tâˆ’yÏ„),0<y<1, f_Y(t)(y)=\tau f_T(t-y\tau),\quad0 < y < 1, In moultmcmc the unobserved start date of the study population is assumed to follow a normal distribution with mean Î¼\mu and standard deviation Ïƒ\sigma, such that FT(t)=Î¦(tâˆ’Î¼Ïƒ)F_T(t)=\Phi\left(\frac{t-\mu}{\sigma}\right) where Î¦\Phi is the standard normal distribution function and fT(t)=Ï•(t)=12Ï€expâˆ’t22f_T(t) = \phi(t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\frac{-t^2}{2}.

    We further assume that FT(t)F_T(t) has pp parameters ğ›‰=Î¸1,Î¸2,â€¦,Î¸p\mathbf{\theta} = \theta_1, \theta_2, \ldots, \theta_p and for convenience the start date Î¼\mu, duration Ï„\tau, and population standard deviation of moult Ïƒ\sigma will be elements of ğ›‰\mathbf{\theta}.

    Likelihoods

    Type 1

    Type 1 data consist of observations of categorical moult state (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult) and sampling is representative in all three categories. The likelihood of these observations is â„’(ğ›‰,t,u,v)=âˆi=1IP(ti)âˆj=1JQ(uj)âˆk=1KR(vk). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,v) = \prod_{i=1}^IP(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^JQ(u_j)\prod_{k=1}^KR(v_k).

    Type 2

    Type 2 data consist of observations of birds in all three moult states (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult). Sampling is representative for all three categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g.Â percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is â„’(ğ›‰,t,u,y,v)=âˆi=1IP(ti)âˆj=1Jq(uj,yj)âˆk=1KR(vk), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y,v) = \prod_{i=1}^IP(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^Jq(u_j,y_j)\prod_{k=1}^KR(v_k), where q(uj,yj)=Ï„fT(ujâˆ’yjÏ„).q(u_j,y_j) = \tau f_T(u_j-y_j\tau).

    Lumped Type 2

    Lumped type 2 data consist of observations of birds in all three moult states (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult), but where the pre-moult and post-moult states cannot be distinguished from each other, yielding II observations of dates tit_i on which non-moulting birds were observed. Sampling is representative for all three categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g.Â percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is â„’(ğ›‰,t,u,y)=âˆi=1IPR(ti)âˆj=1Jq(uj,yj), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y) = \prod_{i=1}^IPR(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^Jq(u_j,y_j), where q(uj,yj)=Ï„fT(ujâˆ’yjÏ„)q(u_j,y_j) = \tau f_T(u_j-y_j\tau) and PR(ti)=P(ti)+R(ti).PR(t_i)=P(t_i)+R(t_i).

    Type 3

    Type 3 data consist of observations of actively moulting birds only, and a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g.Â percent feather mass grown) is known for each individual. The likelihood of these observations is â„’(ğ›‰,u,y)=âˆj=1Jq(uj,yj)Q(uj). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,u,y) = \prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{Q(u_j)}.

    Type 4

    Type 4 data consist of observations of birds in active moult and post-moult only. Sampling is representative for these two categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g.Â percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is â„’(ğ›‰,u,y,v)=âˆj=1Jq(uj,yj)1âˆ’P(uj)âˆk=1KR(vk)1âˆ’P(vk). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,u,y,v) = \prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{1-P(u_j)}\prod_{k=1}^K\frac{R(v_k)}{1-P(v_k)}.

    Type 5

    Type 5 data consist of observations of birds in pre-moult and active moult. Sampling is representative for these two categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g.Â percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is â„’(ğ›‰,t,u,y)=âˆi=1IP(ti)1âˆ’R(ti)âˆj=1Jq(uj,yj)1âˆ’R(uj). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y) = \prod_{i=1}^I\frac{P(t_i)}{1-R(t_i)}\prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{1-R(u_j)}.

    Type 1 + 2

    As outlined in Les G. Underhill and Zucchini (1988) estimates can also be derived from mixtures of data types. Type 1 + 2 data consist of observations of birds in all three moult states (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult). Sampling is representative for all three categories, but a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g.Â percent feather mass grown) is known only for some of the actively moulting birds. This means the sample consist of II pre-moult birds, JJ birds in active moult with known indices, LL birds in active moult without known indices but known capture dates uâ€²=uâ€²l,â€¦,uâ€²Lu'=u'_l,\ldots,u'_L, and KK post-moult birds. The likelihood of these observations is â„’(ğ›‰,t,u,y,uâ€²,v)=âˆi=1IP(ti)âˆj=1Jq(uj,yj)âˆl=1LQ(uâ€²l)âˆk=1KR(vk), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y,u',v) = \prod_{i=1}^IP(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^Jq(u_j,y_j)\prod_{l = 1}^{L}Q(u'_{l})\prod_{k=1}^KR(v_k),

    Recapture models

    moultmcmc currently implements a recaptures model which allows for heterogeneity in start dates Î¼\mu but assumes a common moult duration Ï„\tau. When repeat observations are available an individualâ€™s start date Î¼n\mu_n then becomes

    Î¼n=Î¼0+Î¼â€²n+ğ±Î¼ğ›ƒÎ¼\begin{equation} \mu_n = \mu_0 + \mu'_n + \mathbf{x}_\mu\boldsymbol{\beta}_\mu \end{equation}

    where ğ±Î¼\boldsymbol{x}_\mu is a row vector containing the values of individual-specific predictors (in the same format as ğ—Î¼\boldsymbol{X}_\mu), and Î¼â€²n\mu'_n is an individual-level random effect intercept

    Î¼â€²nâˆ¼Normal(0,Ïƒn)\begin{equation} \mu'_n \sim \mathrm{Normal}(0,\sigma_n) \end{equation} where Ïƒn\sigma_n is the individual-specific standard deviation. We can then exploit the linearity assumption and treat observed moult scores as yniâˆ¼Normal(Î¼0+Î¼â€²n+Ï„*uni,ÏƒÏ„)\begin{equation} y_{ni} \sim \mathrm{Normal}(\mu_0 + \mu'_n + \tau * u_{ni}, \sigma_\tau) \end{equation} where ÏƒÏ„\sigma_\tau captures any unmodelled variance in Ï„\tau as well as any measurement error in yy.

    The likelihood for the Type 3-like model for a sample of JJ birds in active moult without repeated observations, and NN birds in active moult with a total of MM repeated observations uâ€²=uâ€²m,â€¦,uâ€²Mu'=u'_m,\ldots,u'_M and yâ€²=yâ€²m,â€¦,yâ€²My'=y'_m,\ldots,y'_M then is

    â„’(ğ›‰,u,y,uâ€²,yâ€²)=âˆj=1Jq(uj,yj)Q(uj)âˆm=1Mf(uâ€²m,yâ€²m)âˆn=1NÏ•(Î¼â€²n|0,Ïƒn), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,u,y,u',y') = \prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{Q(u_j)}\prod_{m = 1}^{M}f(u'_m,y'_m)\prod_{n=1}^N\phi(\mu'_n|0,\sigma_n), where f(uâ€²m,yâ€²m)f(u'_m,y'_m) follows from above.

    Priors

    Users have a choice between two set of priors for the intercept terms of the linear predictors on the start date Î¼\mu, the duration Ï„\tau, and the population standard deviation of the start date Ïƒ\sigma, respectively. By default flat priors are used for Î¼0\mu_0 and Ï„0\tau_0 and a vaguely informative normal prior on ln(Ïƒ0)\ln(\sigma_0)

    Î¼0âˆ¼Uniform(0,366)\mu_0 \sim \mathrm{Uniform(0,366)}
    Ï„0âˆ¼Uniform(0,366)\tau_0 \sim \mathrm{Uniform(0,366)}
    ln(Ïƒ0)âˆ¼Normal(0,5)\ln(\sigma_0) \sim \mathrm{Normal(0,5)}

    In some cases the models sample poorly with these priors, and better convergence can be achieved by setting the argument flat_prior = FALSE. In this case vaguely informative truncated normal priors are used for Î¼0\mu_0 and Ï„0\tau_0:

    Î¼0âˆ¼TruncNormal(150,50,0,366)\mu_0 \sim \mathrm{TruncNormal(150,50,0,366)}
    Ï„0âˆ¼TruncNormal(100,30,0,366)\tau_0 \sim \mathrm{TruncNormal(100,30,0,366)}

    These priors work well for data from passerines in seasonal environments, i.e.Â when the sampling occasion data is encoded as days from mid-winter.

    For any additional regression coefficients an improper flat prior is used as a default.

    Underhill, Les G., and Walter Zucchini. 1988. â€œA Model for Avian Primary Moult.â€ Ibis 130: 358â€“72. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1474-919x.1988.tb00993.x.

    1. Note that in Les G. Underhill and Zucchini (1988) the variable tt is doubly defined. It is both a generic variable of time in the model derivation, and denotes the sample dates of pre-moult birds in the data likelihoodsâ†©ï¸
